item.title: Metaphor: ReFantazio's Massive Official Strategy Guide Up For Preorder At Amazon
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/metaphor-refantazios-massive-official-strategy-guide-up-for-preorder-at-amazon/1100-6528507/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Metaphor: ReFantazio is getting an official strategy guide on February 28, 2025, and you can preorder it now at Amazon for $55. Published by Future Press, the Metaphor: ReFantazio Strategy Guide is a 592-page hardcover book featuring mountains of information and full-color images "that recaptures Atlus's wonderfully unique style on the printed page," according to the Amazon listing.

Official strategy guides are uncommon these days, and this is the first one for an Atlus game in quite some time. Considering the popularity of Metaphor and Atlus role-playing games in general, we imagine this could sell out, so you may want to secure your preorder soon.

Metaphor: ReFantazio Official Strategy Guide (Hardcover)

$55 | Releases February 28, 2025

Metaphor: ReFantazio's massive official strategy guide sounds like both an awesome collectible for Atlus fans and a comprehensive compendium of everything you could possibly want to know about the game.

Along with a complete walkthrough designed so that you see and do everything, the guidebook has multiple catalogs of useful information to pore over:

  • Archetype Encyclopedia: An exhaustive section covering all skills, Synthesis attacks, and inheritance options.
  • Equipment catalog: All items and equipment are included in a section designed to be used as a quick reference sheet.
  • Bestiary: Every enemy in the game is chronicled with in-depth stats, including strengths and weaknesses, item drop rates, and other pertinent details.
  • Dialogue trees: All of the choice-based dialogue and actions made in the game are outlined to help you form bonds with characters based on your personal preferences.
  • Appendices: For those who want true 100% completion, this section contains the full Memorandum, has New Game+ details, an achievements and trophies guide, and a build guide to help you be as prepared as possible for Metaphor's toughest challenges.

It also comes with a poster-sized map of Euchronia that's an exact replica of the in-game map.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Helldivers 2 Players Crush Illuminate Invaders In Under A Week
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/helldivers-2-players-crush-illuminate-invaders-in-under-a-week/1100-6528505/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

During The Game Awards, Arrowhead Game Studios unleashed a new Helldivers 2 update that introduced the Illuminate, an alien race that was thought to be extinct. In-universe, the Illuminate had over a century to make their plans to invade Super Earth, but the players have already repelled the invasion in just under a week.

As reported by PC Gamer, over 100,000 players checked in with Helldivers 2 over a 24-hour period, the game's highest numbers since April. And the combined forces expelled the Illuminate so thoroughly that this previously feared foe is now the subject of mockery by the triumphant players.

The same account noted that the fight against the Illuminate at Calypso was also one of the bloodiest battles in the game's history.

As this meme points out, the victory over the Illuminate came by a very thin margin, and only because so many players were active. A second wave of the invasion may be a different story, especially if the players can't marshal all of their forces.

Earlier this year, Arrowhead mapped out a 60-day plan to fix some of Helldivers 2's lingering issues, many of which were addressed in a patch that dropped in September. And while a story mode isn't in the cards, Helldivers 2 became one of the fastest-selling PlayStation games of all time, as well as one of GameSpot's picks for the Best Games of 2024.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Capcom "Focusing" On Reviving Other Franchises After Okami 2 And New Onimusha Reveals
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/capcom-focusing-on-reviving-other-franchises-after-okami-2-and-new-onimusha-reveals/1100-6528504/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The 2000s called, and Capcom answered last week by unveiling new entries in the Okami and Onimusha series. But the company doesn't seem done yet with bringing back old franchises. In fact, Capcom states it's "focusing on reactivating dormant IPs" alongside brand-new titles going forward.

A Capcom press release highlighting the reveals of Okami 2 and Onimusha Way of the Sword at The Game Awards offers insight into the publisher's plans for the future. "In addition to regularly releasing major new titles each year, Capcom is focusing on reactivating dormant IPs that haven't had a new title launch recently. The company is working to further enhance corporate value by leveraging its rich library of content, which includes reviving past IPs like [Okami 2 and Onimusha Way of the Sword], in order to continuously produce highly efficient, high-quality titles."

Okami 2--referred as "Okami sequel project" by Capcom--will see the return of the original's director, with Hideki Kamiya. Okami originally launched for PS2 in 2006, and the series did get a follow-up in 2010 (2011 for North America) with Okamiden for Nintendo DS. There is no release window for the Okami sequel project.

Meanwhile, Ominusha Way of the Sword is set to arrive in 2026 on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S. It's the first new entry in the mainline series since 2006's Onimusha: Dawn of Dreams for PS2.

It's not necessarily new for Capcom to note that it's looking into old franchises to revisit, by the way. In 2019, Capcom discussed intentions to "utilize" dormant franchises. In addition, earlier this year, the company insisted Mega Man hasn't been forgotten, meaning the Blue Bomber could possibly see a return alongside Okami in the years ahead.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Marvel Rivals Is Introducing Jeff-Centric Mode And New Skins During Its Winter Celebration
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/marvel-rivals-is-introducing-jeff-centric-mode-and-new-skins-during-its-winter-celebration/1100-6528501/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It's time to deck the halls and hit the slopes as Marvel Rivals is bringing a brand-new game mode and skins for its limited-time Winter Celebration event. The Winter Celebration will kick off on December 20 at 4 PM PT / 7 PM ET and introduce Jeff's Winter Splash Festival--a 4v4 Arcade Mode--into the game.

The Splash Festival will feature a four-player mode, with each player controlling Jeff The Land Shark and attempting to bring their opponents down with icy water-breath and whirlpool attacks. Completing tasks will reward players with limited-time items such as the Jeff the Land Shark: Cuddly Fuzzlefin costume, nameplate, spray, and other rewards. There will also be festive new skins for Eddie Brock, Rocket Raccoon, Magik, and Groot.

Eddie has a jagged glacial look, while Magik is sporting some snow bunny gear. Rocket is donned in Santa's scarlet, and Groot is a Christmas tree, even decked out with ornaments and lights.

Marvel also announced a new Marvel Rivals comic book series exclusive to the Marvel Unlimited digital comics app, premiering December 16. There will also be a new set of free character sheets for the Marvel Multiverse Role-Playing Game along with a play map, and a new Domination-inspired game mode on December 20.

Starting January 3, all paid Marvel Unlimited subscribers will receive a redemption code for a special spray for Jeff that'll arrive via their registered email. New subscribers have until December 25 to sign up to receive the spray.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Preorders For It Takes Two Developer's New Game Split Fiction Now Live
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/preorders-for-it-takes-two-developers-new-game-split-fiction-now-live/1100-6528489/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Developer Hazelight has produced several of the best co-op games, and for its next project, the It Takes Two studio is looking to blur the worlds of fantasy and sci-fi together in Split Fiction. Preorders are now live for the game ahead of its March 6, 2025 release, and you can grab a copy of it for PC, Xbox Series X|S, or PS5.

Split Fiction Preorder Bonus

EA has not announced any preorder bonuses for Split Fiction, but we'll update this post if any are confirmed.

Split Fiction

$50 | Releases March 6, 2025

Split Fiction is currently available in a $50 standard edition. It includes the base game plus a cross-play Friend Pass, which allows one user who owns the game to invite a pal to join them, even if they haven't purchased it--meaning you only need to purchase one copy of the game to play this co-op adventure. And since it's cross-play, you PS5, Xbox, and PC players can all play together.

Physical PS5 and Xbox Series X preorders are available at Best Buy. Digital preorders are available on PC, Xbox, and PS5.

First revealed at The Game Awards 2024, Split Fiction tells the story of Mio and Zoe, two would-be writers virtually transported into the fictional worlds they've created, and now have to rely on each other to escape back to the real world. Like other Hazelight-developed games, Split Fiction is a two-player co-op experience, and both players will get to master various abilities as they work their way through each level. There are also optional side stories to dive into, based on stories from Zoe and Mio's pasts that they worked on as kids or teens or started in adulthood but never finished. You can read more about the game in our Split Fiction preview.

item.title: Visions of Mana Is Just $40 For PS5 And Xbox Series X.
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/visions-of-mana-is-just-40-for-ps5-and-xbox-series-x/1100-6528498/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Visions of Mana arrived earlier this, marking the first time in 15 years we've seen a new mainline game in the Mana series. Though it launched to mixed reviews, it’s been a relative hit with longtime fans thanks to its unique watercolor-like graphics and an engaging class system that offers a variety of playstyles. If you were on the fence about the game, now is a good time to finally dive in, as Amazon, Best Buy, and GameStop are all offering it for $40 (was $70). That’s the lowest price we’ve ever seen for the RPG, though it’s unclear how long it’ll stick around.

Visions of Mana

$40 (was $70)

Visions of Mana is an RPG that follows Val and Hinna as they venture towards the Mana Tree. Our Visions of Mana review found the storyline to be rather lackluster, but the game’s vibrant graphics are easy on the eyes and make the adventure feel like a living watercolor painting. You’ll engage in fast-paced battles throughout your journey and encounter a variety of enemies--and at just $40, now is the ideal time to finally check out the first mainline Mana title in 15 years.

Most locations can get the game in their hands before Christmas, though be sure to double-check your arrival dates after entering your shipping details.

If you’re looking for a PS5 version, your best option is to buy it directly from Amazon, as it comes with an exclusive sticker set. If you’re shopping for Xbox Series X, however, you’ll find it listed for $45 on Amazon. Instead, check out Best Buy, which is offering both PS5 and Xbox Series X versions for just $40.

GameStop also has the games listed at a discount--but since you’ll need to pay for shipping unless you spend $79, only shop here if you can opt for in-store pickup.
